Award.AwardTitle: ChANgE Chem Lab: Cognitive Apprenticeship for Engineers in Chem Lab

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
ChANge Chem Lab will improve the quality of STEM education by transforming the laboratory curriculum of undergraduate general chemistry for engineers. This builds on the success of a prior NSF-funded TUES project (DUE-1245068). The curriculum will provide a rich context grounded in the Grand Challenges for Engineering, ensuring a relevant and engaging experience for students. Development activities will include inquiry-based laboratory experiments and support materials that emulate and make explicit an engineer's way of thinking, learning, and collaborating. Student success will be supported by design structures that engage deep learning strategies and which embody our understanding of effective learning in the laboratory. This approach has been shown to support the retention of underrepresented student groups.

ChANgE Chem Lab will generate further evidence regarding how to utilize the potential of laboratory experiments to improve student learning and broaden participation in STEM. This will be achieved by building upon the intellectual merit of prior work (DUE-1245068), which produced a validated model of project-based learning that supports the retention of underrepresented students. Cognitive apprenticeships will provide the theoretical framework to develop six new engineering design projects for the undergraduate general chemistry lab. Each project will include three weeks of inquiry-based experiments and support materials. The project will directly involve more than 600 students, 15 teaching assistants, and five instructors. This approach has been shown to increase the retention of all students, and this project will address the low retention rate of college for students majoring in engineering during the first two-years and broaden participation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of the ChANgE Chem Lab project (1625378) was to systematically build a new laboratory curriculum for general chemistry for engineers that not only focused on the essential chemical concepts, but was intentionally designed for motivating and building the professional identity of undergraduate engineering students. For historically underrepresented students, the culture of introductory STEM courses is notoriously unwelcoming, which leads to cynicism, discouragement, and ultimately abandonment of the career path. Our career-forward approach was intended to break this barrier in order to promote: (1) the utility of chemistry in the engineering discipline, (2) student identity as an apprentice engineer, and (3) commitment to engineering as an area of study and future profession.

 Using the National Academy of Engineering?s Grand Challenges as inspiration and context, we created a collection of eight Design Challenges where students use their understanding of chemistry to explore solutions to complex, open-ended, and socially-relevant engineering problems. They worked on these Challenges collaboratively as small teams adopting the roles of engineers in an engineering firm. For example, one Design Challenge tasked the student teams with optimizing a sequestration protocol for carbon dioxide and submitting a formal recommendation to a hypothetical energy company. Numerous parameters of the process were tested in the laboratory and then optimized by taking into account physical and financial constraints. Design Challenges all resulted in a formal document typical of the engineering discipline, such as a technical memo, executive summary, or scientific abstract.

 When students learn using these Challenges in our model, they better understand themselves in relation to their goal of being a professional engineer, which sustains their confidence, builds their identity with the profession, and improves their professional skills and STEM abilities. This approach affords a more inclusive learning experience than the current inquiry-based model and is effective at addressing the negative STEM culture barrier. As one student indicated, "Our lab format bolsters our learning experience. It truly made me feel like I was figuring out the solution to an important and applicable real-life problem.". Another stated "The laboratory activities were very enlightening and challenged the way I traditionally think about problem solving. "  Analysis showed that the key elements for success are slightly different for different groups of students, but the concept of professional identity is the strongest predictor for the persistence of students from historically underrepresented backgrounds. As a project team, we find these results to be quite encouraging and, if implemented in other institutions, the model is likely to have systemic benefit across the engineering and STEM disciplines.

 A diverse team of faculty and graduate students from the colleges of education, liberal arts and sciences, and engineering worked together on this project. The team enjoyed and has come to ascribe great value to this opportunity for collaborative work. In doing so, they gained new perspectives about people and practices outside of their own fields and learned to better communicate across disciplinary boundaries. Lasting relationships based upon a mutual commitment to inclusive STEM learning experiences and success for all students were forged.

Materials associated with this project are available for use by any interested party and are currently enjoyed by hundreds of students each year in the two-semester sequence of General Chemistry Laboratory for Engineers I & II at the University of Florida.
